title: Thursday, 5th January, 2017
bodyHTML:

PM11:06am

11:06 am

at Tokyo's Tsukjii market

PM11:07am

Let me take you to the Nikkei Asian Review...

PM11:07am

In the first tuna auction of 2017 at Tokyo's Tsukiji wholesale fish market on Thursday, a 212kg bluefin tuna from Oma, Aomori Prefecture, in northern Japan fetched 74.2 million yen ($636,000), the highest price in four years.

That translates to around $3,000 per kilogram, five times more expensive than the highest price at last year's first auction.

It was the highest bid since 2013, when a tuna was sold for a record $1.33 million.

Kiyomura, the operator of the Sushizanmai chain of restaurants, ended up winning the auction for the sixth straight year amid tough bidding. Prices rose amid competition from rivals Tsukiji Sushiko and Genki Sushi, which took part in the New Year's auction for the first time.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

http://asia.nikkei...s-new-year-auction

11:10 am
PM11:10am

PM11:10am

Fed minutes last night

PM11:11am

No real surprises there -- the Fed is awaiting Trumpism

11:11 am
PM11:11am

So there's precious little market reaction -- cos everyone was already awaiting Trumpism

PM11:12am

Have some Steve Englander

PM11:12am

Citi

11:12 am
PM11:12am

I approached the Minutes thinking they would be no more hawkish than the Press Conference and Statement, but there are a number of warning balloons sent up that go beyond Yellen’s Press Conference comments. The key shift in their thinking is that fiscal stimulus changes the meaning of ‘gradual’, changes the definition of easy/tight financial conditions, and changes equilibrium values for rates. If fiscal disappoints we are back where we were in October, but fiscal stimulus when they think we are so near full employment brings us to a new ball game

PM11:12am

For trading the key in the near term will be whether Fed speakers follow up on the Minutes comment on reinvestment. In the short term the emphasis placed on the UR means there is sensitivity if it backs up to 4.8% rather than the expected 4.7% (I think the risk is higher than priced in link.)

PM11:13am

Key quotes from the FOMC Minutes are below. Bolds are mine.

“A couple of participants expressed concern that the Committee’s communications about a gradual pace of policy firming might be misunderstood as a commitment to only one or two rate hikes per year; participants agreed that policy would need to respond appropriately to the evolving outlook. Several participants noted circumstances that might warrant changes to the path for the federal funds rate could also have implications for the reinvestment of proceeds from maturing Treasury securities and principal payments from agency debt and mortgage-backed securities.”

The reinvestment part is more important than the ‘gradual’ part. This is the first time that the Fed portfolio has been brought up so explicitly in a policy framework. Till now the view has been that you need rate hikes to be well underway and then reinvestment becomes an issue.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

This is also striking:

“Most participants attributed the substantial changes in financial market conditions over the intermeeting period-- including the increase in longer-term interest rates, the strengthening of the dollar, the rise in equity prices, and the narrowing of credit spreads--to expectations for more expansionary fiscal policies in coming years or to possible reductions in corporate tax rates. Many participants expressed the need for caution in evaluating the implications of recent financial market developments for the economic outlook, in light of the uncertainty about how federal spending, tax, and regulatory policies might unfold and how global economic and financial conditions will evolve"

BE11:13am

(@erlkin: http://www.npr.org...a-sentence-with-so )

PM11:13am

This doesn’t look hawkish but is. In the past when the Fed has worried about financial conditions it has always been in the context of neutral (or even tightening fiscal policy). So tightening financial conditions are unambiguously contractionary. When financial conditions tighten because of fiscal stimulus that is not contractionary in the same way because activity is expected to be as strong or stronger.

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Had they wanted to warn that financial conditions were tightening to fast they would have done so explicitly by warning of potholes to activity or even lowering short term forecasts. The emphasis was:

PM11:14am

“… almost all also indicated that the upside risks to their forecasts for economic growth had increased as a
result of prospects for more expansionary fiscal policies in coming years.”

PM11:14am

Note also that the above and below comments are the only reference to ‘almost all’ or most’ participants. With the exception of the last one below they all point to a relative hawkish stance.

“with almost all anticipating that the unemployment rate over the next couple of years would run below their estimates of its longer-run normal level.

“Most participants viewed the cumulative progress in the labor market as having brought labor market conditions to or close to those consistent with the Committee’s maximum employment objective.”

“Most participants expected that if economic growth remained moderate, as they projected, the unemployment rate would be only modestly below their estimates of the longer-run normal rate of unemployment over the next few years…”

11:14 am
PM11:14am

This is also striking:
“Many participants judged that the risk of a sizable undershooting of the longer-run normal unemployment rate had increased somewhat and that the Committee might need to raise the federal funds rate more quickly than currently anticipated to limit the degree of undershooting and stem a potential buildup of inflationary pressures.”
Note the words – ‘many’, “sizable” “more quickly than currently anticipated” – these are fighting words for a central bank

PM11:14am

There was a bit of uncertainty about the unemployment rate and that is certainly a risk for Friday if it backs up more than expected, but this was not really emphasized.

PM11:15am

The dovish wing persists,
“A gradual pace was also viewed by some participants as likely to be warranted because the proximity of the federal funds rate to the effective lower bound placed constraints on the ability of monetary policy to respond to adverse shocks to the aggregate demand for goods and services.”

11:14 am
PM11:15am

And
“a few participants suggested that part of the decline might be reversed in coming months”
But fiscal stimulus again makes their challenge much weaker because it diminishes the risk of a negative shock and the risk of reversal was cited by only a ‘few’.

PM11:15am

Think that covers that particular base

PM11:16am

In terms of equities, no reaction

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:22am

The trading update reads very reassuringly. It confirms that the group had a good autumn selling season and it looks likely to deliver 2016 results broadly in line with our expectations. The group has impressively increased both volumes and margins during 2016, despite fears post Brexit. Net cash of £913m at the end of 2016 is significantly better than what we were expecting, presumably due to a better than expected working capital performance. The group continues to open new businesses and invest in land with c.18,700 plots being acquired in 2016. At this early stage no comment was made on the 2017 outlook but the group is clearly in a strong position with a good order book and balance sheet as we enter an arguably more uncertain macro outlook in 2017. Shares look well supported with a solid c.6% dividend yield. All eyes are now on the spring selling season. While 2017 consensus estimates remain within a wide range, the good momentum from H2 2016 into 2017 may encourage some of the lower end to revise numbers up.

BE11:22am

Update Details Summary
Revenue for 2016 of £3.14bn is broadly in line with our forecast with completions up by +4% to 15,171 and the ASP up +4% to £206.7m.
Gross margins are also expected to have improved in the second half.
Second half sales rate was +15% ahead of the prior year.
Forward sales position at the end of 2016 was £1,230m, up by +12%.
During the year the group invested in 18,700 plots of land and will open a new business in Nottingham in January 2017.
Net cash balances at the end of 2016 were much higher than we expected at £913m (2015:£570m).

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Valuation
Shares have stabilised around the current level over the last five months after bouncing strongly post the sharp Brexit vote related sell-off. They reside on a 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.2.1 times versus the sector average of c.1.6 times and offer a committed dividend yield of c.+6%. Premium rating to the sector is deserved, in our view, given its relative performance and strong balance sheet.

BE11:32am

UK Equity Outlook: Recovery & The 6Ds
Despite high-level domestic uncertainty (Brexit), our outlook for UK equities remains bullish and we target FTSE 7600 for end-2017. UK shares historically perform well with weaker GBP (in local terms), providing there is no recession. We expect a commodity-driven earnings recovery in 2017 following a 50%+ fall in UK EPS since 2012 and focus on six key themes: 1) Delta/recovery, 2) Delivery, 3) Dividends/cyclical yield, 4) De-equitisation, 5) Dollar hedge, 6) De-rated domestics.
Big UK Sectors: Banks, Oil & Gas, Pharma, Mining
Andy Coombs & the UK Banks team are positive on international UK banks, less so on domestic ones where EPS remains under pressure. Alastair Syme & the UK Oil team are generally positive on their sector with global supply improvements supporting higher oil prices. They prefer BP over RDS, with RDS looking over-reliant on an oil recovery. Andrew Baum & the UK Pharma team see post-US election industry M&A risk. They prefer Shire which combines rapid growth and low ratings. Heath Jansen & the UK Mining team see industry behavior driving value creation and prefer BHP Billiton, South 32 and Glencore amongst the big caps.
Key UK stocks for 2017
We highlight some key UK stocks for 2017: Ashtead, AZN, BAT, BP, BHP Billiton, Compass, Direct Line, Dixons Carphone, easyJet, Experian, Land Securities, Johnson Matthey, Standard Chartered, Pearson, Rolls Royce, Sage, Shire, Tesco, and Unilever.

BE11:37am

Hm. Sector note, this.

BE11:37am

Civil Aero – what changed? (1) Whilst programme execution is still a risk
for ECA in 2017, comments from some companies in late 2016 (e.g. MTU,
Zodiac) suggest they are closer to the end of “the great product transition”
that has challenged the industry since 2014. (2) Many airlines lowered profit
guidance / deferred aircraft deliveries in 2016, and some airlines could do
this in 2017; but an improving economic backdrop probably provides
respite to the airline industry as a whole. (3) The rally in the $ vs the euro
and sterling in late 2016 is positive for the earnings of ECA companies.

BE11:38am

European Defence – many positives: (1) We believe a multi-year upturn in
global defence spending is about to begin. (2) European Defence trades at a
notable discount to US Defence. (3) Potential for significantly lower tax
rates in the US and UK. (4) UK Defence companies enjoy a 3-4% yoy
benefit to 2017E EPS if the FX rate remains $1.25/£1.

In terms of Rolls, it's in part the very confusing way it adds up its books.

PM11:40am

It's always been confusing the way it adds up its books

BE11:40am

Rolls-Royce is a much less profitable company than we had thought: In 2018 RR will introduce IFRS 15 accounting which will mean it can no longer capitalise
losses on new civil aero engines; no longer smooth profit over new engines and the aftermarket; and no longer recognise aftermarket revenue / profit annually, but
only when a shop visit occurs. On November 16, 2016, RR provided 2015pf results for its Civil Aerospace division assuming IFRS 15 was already in place. In Table
19 below we show our estimate of RR's “clean EBITA margin”, at a group level, assuming IFRS 15 were in place from 2015 onwards. Although IFRS 15 does not
impact RR’s FCF in any way, it is likely to significantly depress reported EBITA through to c2022/23; after c2022/23 RR may have higher EBITA than it would
have under the current accounting regime.

BE11:50am

The recent oil price rally has driven E&P share prices closer to our estimated fair values. The sector is now discounting an average Brent price of US$71/bbl flat (see Figure 3), close to our US$74/bbl long-term forecast but significantly ahead of the Forward Curve, which rises to US$60/bbl in the 2020s (after an initial period in backwardation).

BE11:51am

Here's Fig 3.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

BE11:51am

And here's what if thinks you should take profit in.

BE11:52am

As a result, we are downgrading recommendations on many of our covered stocks (See Figures 1 and 2 for full details and EPS changes). Key changes include AkerBP d/g to Neutral, Cairn d/g to Neutral, Faroe d/g to Neutral, Ithaca d/g to Neutral, Lundin d/g to Underperform, Ophir d/g to Neutral, Premier d/g to Neutral, Tullow d/g to Neutral. Apart from Premier, all of these downgrades are made solely on share price movement bases. On Premier, alongside our recommendation change, we have reduced our TP from 103p to 80p on lowered expectations for Solan production due to P2 underperformance.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Reinstatement of more positive views on these stocks require one (or more) of the following:

1) Share prices coming back

2) An uplift to our oil price assumptions (currently US$61, US$68, US$74 for 2016, 17, 18+)

3) Tangible value creating opportunities that the market should either be willing to pay for in advance, or successful delivery of those opportunities (that are not already included in our valuations). We highlight AkerBP and Tullow as high quality names that should generate said opportunities. We will be waiting to identify (and therefore value) these opportunities in upcoming trading statements.

Cairn Energy PLC (CNE:LSE): Last: 236.20, down 3.9 (-1.62%), High: 238.50, Low: 232.10, Volume: 298.90k
Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 95.75, down 0.5 (-0.52%), High: 97.00, Low: 95.25, Volume: 511.09k
11:53 am

BE11:54am

And in terms of what to buy ... Hurricane .....

BE11:54am

(What on earth is Hurricane?)

11:54 am
PM11:55am

It's london listed apparently

BE11:55am

Hurricane offers 82%+ upside to our target price from the current share price, and has the clearest near-term tangible value creation opportunities, in our view.

Further exploratory drilling (ongoing) and progress on the Lancaster development could add significant value, building on the success the company enjoyed in 2016.

We believe Africa Oil offers very attractive longer term upside through de-risking of the South Lokichar development in Kenya with significant progress expected over the next 12 months. The cash position also provides a safety net for valuations and the current drilling programme should add further resource volumes, in our view. EnQuest is our pick for further oil price leverage combined with low risk project progression (Kraken first oil expected 1H17). Although the rest of the sector now reflects a much higher discounted oil price than it did four months ago, EnQuest is still discounting US$63/bbl, the same number it was back in August 2016. We believe the valuation gap will be narrowed in the coming months once the market starts to believe in Kraken delivery (again, we highlight what happened to the Ithaca share price when Stella delivery became firm).

BE11:55am

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Actually it's a review of 2016 so suits that it is rear view mirror

BE11:57am

(@Boncoeur: Teeth smile )

PM11:57am

When compared to 2015’s calamity and capitulation, 2016 will be remembered as the year of China-led recovery for commodity prices, backed up by reflation expectations. On an indexed basis, almost every major commodity (ex-agriculture) showed price gains as demand surprised on the upside and supply growth stalled. On an annual average basis, however, the majority still recorded YoY declines owing to the time spent in the depths of the deflationary vortex over Q1.
 2017 is beginning with many of the same supportive factors – a global manufacturing recovery, inflation expectations rising, and the China liquidity tap still open if not flowing quite as powerfully. However, in an environment of elevated political turmoil where global economic growth is yet to meaningfully accelerate, the duration of such support is the key 2017 factor, particularly given many prices are now invoking a supply response. For metals and bulk commodities, any signs of weakness in Chinese construction activity should be closely monitored, while for oil much depends on supply-side discipline. And as ever, what happens in the oil markets is highly important for inflation expectations and thus financial market interest in commodities as a whole.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

British American Tobacco's (NYSE: BTI) proposed takeover of Reynolds America (NYSE: RAI) hit a snag, according to a person claiming to have knowledge of the matter. The exact nature of the complication wasn't made clear.

Reynolds last year acknowledged that it received a non-binding proposal from British American Tobacco to purchase the remaining 58% in RAI that it does not currently own, and British American tobacco was widely expected to sweeten its rumored $47 billion offer for RAI in December.

A final agreement was expected early this year, but given the newest complication, a potential transaction may be less likely near-term.

Representatives from BAT and RAI couldn't be reached to comment.

PM12:03pm

Nothing more?

BE12:04pm

Yep, that's the lot. One source and no info. Which is a bit of an odd way to put information into the always febrile M&A arb community.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Jefferies has a guess at what it might mean.

BE12:05pm

We
believe this is likely to do with how BAT is choosing to sweeten the deal
(favouring a change in structure over a larger increase to the absolute
offer). If (as we suspect) the deal is being driven by access to Reynolds
heat not burn technology, we would expect the deal to still complete after
further negotiation, especially also now given potential support from lower
corporation taxes.

BE12:05pm

In fact, it's quite a long guess.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Snag likely around the increase to absolute offer: An article before Christmas
(Sunday Times) suggested that negotiations over the past two months have centered on
altering the balance of the offer, as well as raising the price. We believe the snag at present
revolves around how much of an outlined additional $8 cash sweetener (as suggested in
the article) is used to reduce the stock element and how much is used to bump the offer
(BAT favouring the former and Reynolds favouring the latter in our view).
If vapour is the catalyst then expect a deal to be done: We are of the view that the
catalyst for BAT's current bid for Reynolds is access to Reynolds heat not burn technology
(Revo 2) which we believe is more advanced than what BAT currently has. This technology
(in our opinion) will be important to keep pace with PMI in the race for global vapour
share. With potential vapour value at BAT (ex any US presence) should it be able to compete
effectively worth around £6 per share or more, then we believe there is sizeable incentive
for BAT to pay up.
Standalone price of Reynolds would also suggest a larger bump: While access to
the vapour technology is what we believe will be the key factor to push a deal over the line
at a higher price, there is further incentive for BAT when looking at Reynolds standalone
valuation. Our standalone target price on Reynolds is at $62 dollars, the current offer
someway below this. The Street target price prior to the bid being announced was c$55,
so the current offer is only a slight premium on this. What's more, there is also now the
potential support from lower corporation taxes which could add at least another $5 per
share to Reynolds valuations.
Still expect deal to be done with an absolute offer around $60: We believe
Reynolds are holding out for around $60. If we are right and BAT does want access to
Reynolds vapour technology then we see BAT ultimately matching these levels. If however
it turns out we are wrong, and BAT does have pending technology to compete effectively
with PMI (especially its PMI's IQOS platform two), then we see chances of a deal not being
reached as greater, although the potential corporation tax benefits may still make it happen.
Greatest risk to Reynolds should a deal not be agreed: In the scenario of a deal not
happening we see greatest downside risk to Reynolds where we think we could see the stock
sell off to c$49-$50. For BAT, we believe the price will be largely unchanged, with possible
upside given unwinding of arbitrage short positions and re-rating to reflect market relief that
BAT is not "over paying" (a popular view that is already priced in to some extent we believe).

BE12:06pm

Corporate tax rate changes ahead? Lower corporate taxes are Trump’s leading priority in returning GDP growth towards 4%. Trump and incoming Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin have discussed
lowering the corporate tax rate to as low as 15%. Changes here would especially benefit companies like RAI with high effective tax rates (37%) thereby complicating deal terms. For this reason, we believe
negotiations will be ongoing until they have some clarity on potential tax reform (of note, incoming Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin has described tax reform as "something that happens absolutely within
the first 90 days of this presidency").
Lower corporate tax rate impact to EPS and valuation?: A 15% corporate tax rate by 2018 (not an unreasonable feat with buy-in from a red House and Senate) would drive roughly 40 incremental
percentage points of EPS growth for Reynolds American. This ranks RAI among the top three beneficiaries of a lower corporate tax rate across our coverage. Also in our 2-stage DCF valuation analysis,
assuming an average ~30% tax rate in 2017-2018 and 15% over the following 8 years would value RAI shares at ~$65/share, an 18% premium to current levels (and well ahead of the current BAT offer
price)
